alert.note: Alert for Charles City; Chesapeake; Gloucester; Hampton, Poquoson; Isle of Wight; James City; Newport News; Norfolk, Portsmouth; Southampton; Suffolk; Surry; Sussex; York (Virginia) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Wakefield (Eastern Virginia and Southern Maryland)
info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued May 21 at 8:20PM EDT by NWS Wakefield
info.description: ...Strong thunderstorms will impact portions of Isle of Wight, northeastern Southampton, York, east central Sussex, southern James City, southern Gloucester, southeastern Charles City, and Surry Counties, the City of Poquoson, the northwestern City of Chesapeake, the City of Hampton, the City of Newport News, the western City of Portsmouth, the northeastern City of Suffolk and the City of Williamsburg through 900 PM EDT... At 820 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking strong thunderstorms along a line extending from near Ivor to near Newport News to Driver. Movement was north at 35 mph. HAZARD...Winds in excess of 40 mph, pea size hail and rainfall 1 to 2 inches. SOURCE...Radar indicated. IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects. Minor damage to outdoor objects is possible. Localized flooding of poor drainage and low lying areas. Locations impacted include... Newport News, Hampton, Williamsburg, Smithfield, Gloucester Courthouse, Windsor, Wakefield, Surry, Langley AFB, Queens Lake, Gloucester Point, Churchland, Virginia Institute For Marine Sciences, College Of William And Mary, Christopher Newport University, Patrick Henry Field, Seaford, Chesapeake, Portsmouth and Suffolk. MAX HAIL SIZE...0.25 IN MAX WIND GUST...45 MPH
info.instruction: If outdoors, consider seeking shelter inside a building. Strong wind gusts are possible with these storms. These wind gusts are capable of knocking down tree limbs, small or weakened trees, and blowing around trash cans, potted plants, lawn furniture, and other light outdoor objects. Torrential rainfall is also occurring with these storms and may lead to localized flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded roadways. These storms may intensify, so be certain to monitor local radio stations and available television stations for additional information and possible warnings from the National Weather Service.
